math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="R^{{3}}" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:msup xml:id="m1.1.3" xref="m1.1.3.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.1" xref="m1.1.1.cmml">R</m:mi><m:mn xml:id="m1.1.2.1" xref="m1.1.2.1.cmml">3</m:mn></m:msup><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:apply xml:id="m1.1.3.cmml" xref="m1.1.3"><m:csymbol cd="ambiguous" xml:id="m1.1.3.1.cmml">superscript</m:csymbol><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.1">R</m:ci><m:cn type="integer" xml:id="m1.1.2.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.2.1">3</m:cn></m:apply></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">R^{{3}}</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

math.3: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="[0,T_{{0}}]" xml:id="m3.1" display="inline" xref="m3.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m3.1a" xref="m3.1.cmml"><m:mrow xml:id="m3.1.7" xref="m3.1.7.cmml"><m:mo xml:id="m3.1.7a" xref="m3.1.7.cmml">[</m:mo><m:mrow xml:id="m3.1.7b" xref="m3.1.7.cmml"><m:mn xml:id="m3.1.2" xref="m3.1.2.cmml">0</m:mn><m:mo xml:id="m3.1.7c" xref="m3.1.7.cmml">,</m:mo><m:msub xml:id="m3.1.7.2" xref="m3.1.7.2.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m3.1.4" xref="m3.1.4.cmml">T</m:mi><m:mn xml:id="m3.1.5.1" xref="m3.1.5.1.cmml">0</m:mn></m:msub></m:mrow><m:mo xml:id="m3.1.7d" xref="m3.1.7.cmml">]</m:mo></m:mrow><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m3.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m3.1"><m:apply xml:id="m3.1.7.cmml" xref="m3.1.7"><m:interval closure="closed" xml:id="m3.1.7.1.cmml"/><m:cn type="integer" xml:id="m3.1.2.cmml" xref="m3.1.2">0</m:cn><m:apply xml:id="m3.1.7.2.cmml" xref="m3.1.7.2"><m:csymbol cd="ambiguous" xml:id="m3.1.7.2.1.cmml">subscript</m:csymbol><m:ci xml:id="m3.1.4.cmml" xref="m3.1.4">T</m:ci><m:cn type="integer" xml:id="m3.1.5.1.cmml" xref="m3.1.5.1">0</m:cn></m:apply></m:apply></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m3.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m3.1.cmml">[0,T_{{0}}]</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35Q35 35D35 76A15 classical solution; liquid crystal flows serial article Ma, Shixiang Number: 6109985 Classical solutions for the compressible liquid crystal flows with nonnegative initial densities. 2013 Summary: In this paper, we study the Cauchy problem of the simplified Ericksen-Leslie system modeling compressible nematic liquid crystal flows in math1 . We first prove the local existence of the strong solutions provided that the data satisfies a natural compatibility condition. Then by deriving the smoothing effect of the solution in math2 , we conclude that it is indeed classical on some time interval math3 . Here we do not need the condition that initial density is bounded below away from zero.

math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="\mathbb{R}^{2}" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:msup xml:id="m1.1.3" xref="m1.1.3.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.1" xref="m1.1.1.cmml">ℝ</m:mi><m:mn xml:id="m1.1.2.1" xref="m1.1.2.1.cmml">2</m:mn></m:msup><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:apply xml:id="m1.1.3.cmml" xref="m1.1.3"><m:csymbol cd="ambiguous" xml:id="m1.1.3.1.cmml">superscript</m:csymbol><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.1">ℝ</m:ci><m:cn type="integer" xml:id="m1.1.2.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.2.1">2</m:cn></m:apply></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">\mathbb{R}^{2}</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

math.8: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="\gamma" xml:id="m8.1" display="inline" xref="m8.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m8.1a" xref="m8.1.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m8.1.1" xref="m8.1.1.cmml">γ</m:mi><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m8.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m8.1"><m:ci xml:id="m8.1.1.cmml" xref="m8.1.1">γ</m:ci></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m8.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m8.1.cmml">\gamma</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35Q92 35B44 35C06 92C17 Keller-Segel; chemotaxis; two-species model; Cauchy problem; radial solutions; blowup sharp criteria serial article Dickstein, Flávio Number: 6109971 Sharp conditions for blowup of solutions of a chemotactical model for two species in math1 . 2013 Summary: We consider a model system of Keller-Segel type for the evolution of two species in the whole space math2 which are driven by chemotaxis and diffusion. It is well known that this problem admits global and blowup solutions. We show that there exists a sharp condition which allows to distinguish global and blowup solutions in the radially symmetric case. More precisely, let math3 and math4 be the total masses of the species. Then there exists a critical curve math5 in the math6 plane such that the solution blows up if and only if math7 is above math8 . This gives an answer to a question raised by C. Conca, E. Espejo and K. Vilches [Eur. J. Appl. Math. 22, No. 6, 553–580 (2011; Zbl 1241.35025)]. We also study the asymptotic behaviour of global solutions in the subcritical case, showing that they are asymptotically self-similar.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C50 Co-PI matrix; Laplacian matrix; Co-PI Laplacian matrix; Co-PI eigenvalue; Laplacian Co-PI eigenvalue; Co-PI index serial article Su, Guifu; Xiong, Liming; Xu, Lan Number: 1254.05111 On the Co-PI and Laplacian Co-PI eigenvalues of a graph. 2013 Summary: In this paper we present an equivalent definition of Co-PI index and then determine the eigenvalues of Co-PI matrices and their Laplacians of Cartesian product graphs, including bounds on the second and third Co-PI spectral moment of a graph. The explicit formulae for the Co-PI index of Cartesian product graphs are also presented.

math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="p" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.1" xref="m1.1.1.cmml">p</m:mi><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.1">p</m:ci></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">p</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05A16 06B99 60C05 82C41 vicious walkers serial article Feierl, Thomas Number: 1254.05022 The height and range of watermelons without wall. 2013 Summary: We determine the weak limit of the distribution of the random variables “height” and “range” on the set of math1 -watermelons without wall restriction as the number of steps tends to infinity. Additionally, we provide asymptotics for the moments of the random variable “height”.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 47 Toeplitz operator; Hankel operator; Dirichlet space; finite rank serial article Lee, Young Joo Number: 6109976 Finite rank sums of products of Toeplitz and Hankel operators. 2013 Summary: On the Dirichlet space of the unit disk, we consider operators which are finite sums of Toeplitz products, Hankel products or products of Toeplitz and Hankel operators. We then give characterizations of when such operators have finite rank on the Dirichlet space.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 39B52 39-01 39B99 43A62 book Székelyhidi, László Number: 6110093 Functional equations on hypergroups. 2013 Preliminary review / Publisher’s description: The theory of hypergroups is a rapidly developing area of mathematics due to its diverse applications in different areas like probability, harmonic analysis, etc. This book exhibits the use of functional equations and spectral synthesis in the theory of hypergroups. It also presents the fruitful consequences of this delicate “marriage” where the methods of spectral analysis and synthesis can provide an efficient tool in characterization problems of function classes on hypergroups. This book is written for the interested reader who has open eyes for both functional equations and hypergroups, and who dares to enter a new world of ideas, a new world of methods – and, sometimes, a new world of unexpected difficulties.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35P30 35Q51 spectral problem; nonlinear evolution equations; algebro-geometric solution serial article Zhai, Yunyun; Geng, Xianguo Number: 6109982 Straightening out of the flows for the Hu hierarchy and its algebro-geometric solutions. 2013 Summary: With the help of the Lax matrix, the Hu hierarchy is decomposed into two systems of solvable ordinary differential equations. Based on the theory of algebraic curves, the Abel-Jacobi coordinates are introduced to straighten out all the flows related to the entire hierarchy. Algebro-geometric solutions for the entire Hu hierarchy are obtained by using asymptotic expansion of the meromorphic function and its Riemann theta function representation.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05A15 05B50 inscribed polyomino; enumeration; generating function; irreducible polyomino; prime polyomino serial article Goupil, Alain; Cloutier, Hugo; Pellerin, Marie-Eve Number: 1254.05016 Generating functions for inscribed polyominoes. 2013 Summary: The goal of this paper is to propose a method to construct exact expressions and generating functions for the enumeration of general polyominoes up to translation with respect to area. We illustrate the proposed method with the construction of the generating functions for the polyominoes inscribed in a given math1 rectangle with area min+1 and min+2. These polyominoes are not convex and we use geometric arguments to construct their generating functions. We use a statistic on polyominoes that we call the index and the multiplicative property of a diagonal product of polyominoes. From the main generating functions, we extract the generating functions and exact formulas for convex polyominoes of index one and two. The formulas obtained suggest an asymptotic evaluation for the number math2 of polyominoes of area math3 different from the usual evaluation based on numerical results.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 91 lookback options; stochastic volatility; pricing options; homotopy analysis method serial article Leung, Kwai Sun Number: 6107012 An analytic pricing formula for lookback options under stochastic volatility. 2013 Summary: An analytic pricing formula for floating strike lookback options under Heston’s stochastic volatility model is derived by means of the homotopy analysis method. The fixed strike lookback options can then be priced on the basis of the results of floating strike and the put – call parity relation for lookback options.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 11 sums of products; extended math1 -Euler numbers and polynomials; higher-order extended math2 -Euler numbers and polynomials; alternating Hurwitz math3 -zeta functions; alternating multiple Hurwitz math4 -zeta functions; math5 -Stirling numbers of the first kind serial article Kim, Min-Soo; Lee, Jun Ho Number: 6109978 On sums of products of the extended math6 -Euler numbers. 2013 Summary: In this paper, by expressing the sums of products of the extended math7 -Euler polynomials in terms of the special values of the alternating multiple Hurwitz math8 -zeta function at non-positive integers, we obtain a sums of products identity for the extended math9 -Euler numbers, which is an extension of Satoh’s result for any extended math10 -Euler numbers.
